X1: I have always wanted a vacuuming robot, and was excited to put it to work. We don¡¯t wear shoes in the house and with hardwood floors, you notice every piece of debris either by sight or feel.We bought this at a big-box store and tried hard to love it after a week trial, but ultimately ended up returning it and getting a new Dyson V10 for $50 more.The fact that it cleans is undisputed: the proof is in the bin. Even on floors that appear to be clean, it still can get a lot of hair that would go unnoticed. We liked the way it would hug walls and used the rotating side brush to get into the corners. The issues were with how it cleans and how much attention it required to operate properly, in addition to continued cost-of-ownership through part changes at set intervals.As stated in the function description, it cleans at random: only changing course when it encounters and obstacle. The randomness may be acceptable to some, but when you¡¯re looking at the same debris in the same open spot after two days and have to use a regular vacuum to pick it up, you tend to question what you paid for.Also, the preparation required to make it work properly completely negates the convenience of automation. You will have to pick up everything that could get moved or ingested by the vacuum (shoes, cords, bathroom rugs) and actually move things around so that it doesn¡¯t get stuck (chairs, coffee tables, remembering to close doors to bedrooms). Even with all of this preparation, I would still get an app alert while at work that told me the vacuum got stuck on something or died in a corner while trying to find its way home.Perhaps spending a few more hundred dollars on a premium unit would resolve some of the problems, but others are just inherent in the nature of asking a machine to do something without human intervention.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2020

Found that this works pretty much as well as a standard pet hair vac to clean up most.  She understood how to control it within 2 minutes of my putting the app on her phone.  Dogs and cats leave hair, birds leave lots of seed hulls and seed outside the cage.  Yes I would purchase this again, does it job without question, was impressed with its cleaning up where we were 2 days since we had ran the vacuum.  Well worth the price, it even cleans up under large parrot cages minimizing the need to move them around.

X1: If you have any part of any carpet that has black in it ...  The Roomba will stop and give you an error ...There are what is called CLIFF Sensors, and if those sensors see anything black, they think the Roomba is going off a cliff (or more likely a stairwell) ...  There is NO WAY to turn these sensors off, every web-site about this issue says to tape slips of white paper over the sensors ...  I paid $250 to tape paper over 4 sensors on the Roomba to get it to work ...  Ridiculous !!!  I did the paper trick, worked for awhile, then stopped working ... (Paper got dirty)  so then other sites suggested taking the brand-new Roomba apart (a 2 to 3 hour process with dozens of screws) ....  Pull the LEDs from the sensors and point them at each other ...  Didn't work ...  tried 3 times ...  Hours of frustration ...  Brand new Roomba, $250 dollars into the trash !!!

X1: I would have liked to have written an amazing review about this Roomba, but alas it came in a damaged (as in crushed) shipping box, with evidence that it was NOT a new item (broken seals inside). This crushed box was then shipped to me inside a regular larger box to hide the damage. So, what did I find inside? A dead Robot. No amount of charging would wake the poor thing. It actually looked ok, but obviously something had gone quite wrong. It was dead. I did inspect it carefully and these are the things you may be interested in: It has only one side brush - I thought this was odd for a floor vacuum, but clearly there is not meant to be another one, so it wasn't just missing. It seems to have extra sensors so it won't fall down the stairs - I assume that is what they were for, since I was never able to test it. It has two main brushes that should work in tandem with one another. The Dust bin is regular in size but then there is a weird half cone shaped filter inside of it that takes up a lot of space, so if you could use it there is lots less room for it to actually collect dust. meaning you would have to empty it more often. It does come with a charging dock and cord, it comes with an extra cone filter. It does NOT come with a remote. Since it was DOA that's all I can tell you. so Here are my assumed pros and cons:Pro:it looks nicedual main brushesextra filterdocking stationCons:No remoteonly one side brushfilter takes up a lot of bin spacedocking station power cord must come out only on the right, no option to direct it to the left

X1: My husband had always wanted a Roomba. Obviously I was just as intrigued as the next person with the idea of a robot vacuum, but I never saw the need. Then my husband bought one on and whim and boy, oh, boy. There is no going back for me.Does this Roomba replace a traditional vacuum in a home with three kids, three cats, and a dog? No. But does it help keep said home a whole lot cleaner? Yes!While I do still vacuum frequently, it¡¯s not nearly as often as it used to be. Sometimes I actually vacuum WHILE the Roomba is vacuuming. We¡¯re like a little vacuuming duo and it honestly just makes my heart happy to work alongside my little robot buddy.The Roomba won¡¯t do any deep cleaning, so I will still suck up hair and dirt with my upright vacuum after the Roomba has finished. But it goes the other way as well. I can vacuum a room, then send out the Roomba and it picks up stuff I missed. If you don¡¯t have animals, I think a Roomba could easily be all you need to keep your floors clean.Where the Roomba really shines is for under furniture. If you have animals that love to sleep under couches and beds, you know how hairy things can get under there. I wouldn¡¯t vacuum under my bed nearly often enough. Who wants to be pulling out a huge bed, especially in a small space? Send in the robot! I couldn¡¯t believe how clean the Roomba got the floor the first time I had it clean under my bed!And I love the spot clean feature! I¡¯ve used it on small rugs, to clean up tiny bits of glass after a cup was dropped on the floor, and one of my favorite ways to use it is as a dust pan. I put the Roomba on spot mode and then I sweep toward it. So much easier and faster than sweeping everything into a dust pan.We loved scheduling the vacuum to clean at night while we slept so we could wake up to a freshly vacuumed floor. But then our dog pooped on the floor in the night. I will say that the Roomba did a fairly decent job at cleaning it up. But needless to say, we don¡¯t do that anymore. Now I just start it first thing in the morning.My only complaint is the rotating bristle brushy thing. It started squeaking on the second day we had the Roomba. My husband has to keep greasing it, but the squeaking always comes back in a couple days. Other than that though, this thing is pure magic. If you¡¯re on the fence, just go ahead and get it.

X1: Not bad overall! Both are in the same price range. The Roomba 675 pros: good quality, well packaged, great on carpets due to the dual brush design, easy to clean, very user friendly app, and it easily got over my doorway saddles which are about 3/4 in high. Cons: Its quite loud if its on hardwood, on carpets its fine. Very poor suction on hard surfaces, but it does eventually get the job done just takes a bunch of passes. Doesn't clean as efficiently in a pattern as the Roborock, it just bounces around. If it gets accidentally bumped while charging, it doesn't return to station as easily and quietly as the E5 does. Battery life much lower compared to the Roborock E4 about 2x. In conclusion its really not a bad robovac. I managed to get the Roborock E5 on sale off amazon for $180 and it performed better than the Roomba in my opinion. The roborock does feel cheaper in design and the app is a bit harder to use, but it has 3x the suction and nearly 2x the battery life. Also, due to the gyroscope built in, it actually cleans more efficiently in a pattern, rather than just random bumping around. In conclusion I stuck with the Roborock E4 and returned the Roomba 675. But if you have alot of carpeting, the Roomba 675 wouldn't be a bad choice. Hope this helped if you are in between those two.

The app will alert you when the Roomba has finished its "job" or if the Roomba itself is stuck in a location (it gets stuck often and will absolutely eat your charges and cables). The Roomba will return to the docking station to charge once it has done it's job. The collection container is pretty small, but holds a lot of debris and can be easily dumped. There is a large button on the top of the machine that turns it on and there is also a button to quit the job and return to docking station. There is a battery symbol that lets you know at all times the battery life. X1: We've heard nothing but good things from friends and family who have Roombas, so we thought we'd give it a try. The first thing we were told was, "Make sure you spend the money for the real thing: the others may be a lot cheaper, but they're headaches waiting to happen."  Okay, fine, but the 675 isn't exactly a bank breaker, especially if you get it during a sale. And if we just made our lives easier AND avoided l'agita for less than $250, that's even better.I don't care about packaging until it's inadequate or off-the-charts excessive, and neither was the case here.The setup was breathtakingly simple - I forgot to breathe for a few seconds when I looked at the unit in the charger and after installing/starting the app, pressing 2 buttons, and naming the robot ("Sucka" - I know, that's so original), I saw that my phone was reporting that setup was complete.  I thought, "Really, that's it?  What'd I miss?" As it turns out, I missed nothing. Easy-peasy.  So, I thought I'd just let it charge overnight and then I'd play with it the next day.The next day, while working in my home office, I started the app and selected "Vacuum Everywhere".  I heard it wake up with cheerful little beeps and start working.  It really isn't too loud, so between meetings I followed the sound, coffee in hand, to watch it work.  I was kind of fun to watch it careening around like a drunken toddler, gently crashing into stuff and bouncing counter-clockwise until it could move again. I half-expected it to exclaim, "Uh-oh!"  And if something was light enough, it just pushed it around until it hit something solid enough to make it bounce.  I wish I'd waited until after working hours so that I could watch it with an adult beverage or two.  The 14-year-old in me is definitely going to set up some obstacle tests.Like any toddler, it requires a little bit of supervision. It got stuck on a thick power cable beneath a bed, so it beeped, called out with a voice to ask for help, and alerted my phone app; I rescued it and sent it on its way.  (Note to 14-yr-old-self: see if there's a way to hack the firmware to change the voice alerts to something really wrong. Maybe a toddler-like voice yelling, "Aw, s**t!" or "FML!")Also like a toddler, it eventually needs a diaper change and a feeding/nap. After a while, I had to empty the dust bin and pull some hair off of the brushes and wheels, so I put it back on the charger for a bit.  So, it's napping right now. After lunch, I'll fire it up again and see if it finds its way into my office.It may need some decoration, too.  Maybe some googly-eyes and a rude bumper sticker? Or a tiny pirate flag flying from the rear?So, for the important part: does it clean well?Yes. Judging from look of the floors and the amount of crud in the dustbin, it does a solid job.  And, apparently, I don't: my weekly floor sweeping/Bona mopping appears to be missing some stuff.Ah, the app tells me that it's already back to full charge (just under 2 hours!), so I'm gonna turn Sucka loose again.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2020

X1: Great entry level robot vacuum. We use this to clean the hardwood and rugs in our living room and kitchen and it does a great job cleaning up all the cat and dog hair and all the dirt the pets bring in. The floors are spotless after it runs a full cycle. The Roomba app is great and you can easily set your cleaning schedule or start a new cycle while you're away. You do have to make sure any loose objects are off the floor, so as we leave for the day we take 2 minutes and move the pet food bowls and anything else up and out of the way. Same for any loose cords or curtains that are hanging on the floor.Knocking off one star because it sometimes sometimes freezes when it goes to far out over the ledge between our living room and family room that's one step down. 95% of the time it senses the ledge and turns around, but other times it goes too far out and gets stuck. You have to turn it around yourself and press start again to get it back running. It also sometimes get stuck under the couch. Our couch is just the right height that the Roomba can get under the couch in one certain spot, but then gets stuck. If it was a fraction taller or shorter, it would work just fine. It can be annoying when you expect it to clean the whole area, but get's stuck after just a few minutes of cleaning.It also seems to have a hard time finding it's docking station after it gets done cleaning. It's probably our fault in where we located the docking station, but this spot works for us and is out of the way. We just have to pick up the dead Roomba and carry it back to the dock. Not a huge deal, and the convenience of the robot vacuum outweighs the issue of having to carry it back when it's done.Due to the layout of our house, if it finds it's way into the bedrooms/office, it would usually get stuck back there, so we block off that area of the house now. We didn't feel like spending the large amount of extra money to buy a vacuum that comes with house mapping, so we still vacuum those areas with our cordless stick vacuum.If you're hoping this vacuum will clean your entire house and return to it's charging dock perfectly, you probably need to spend the extra money and buy one with mapping features. But, if you want a vacuum to thoroughly clean you main living areas and save a little money, this is the one for you.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2020

CLEANS CARPETS & HARD FLOORS - Auto-Adjust Cleaning Head automatically adapts its height to effectively clean carpets & hard floors.non of this is remotely true with the possible exception of voice commands which I have not tried. X1: I live in a two bedroom apartment and have managed to keep the floors very clean due to my Roomba. We have it scheduled to run 3 times a week, and I'd say it learned the layout of the apartment within the first 2 weeks. It cleans different sections of the apartment on different days, and gets into its groove more as time goes on, so you just have to trust its process at first.The only slightly annoying issue we've had with the Roomba is that once it starts running, the charge only lasts for an hour and fifteen minutes to ~maybe~ an hour and thirty minutes max. There have been 2 or 3 times where it's just died while cleaning, or died while on its way back to the dock, and then I've had to go grab it and place it on the charging dock manually. However, it is a "robot vacuum", and so I think you need to expect it to have dumb moments like this sometimes.You have to keep floors fairly clean of small objects to, or else the roomba may get stuck on top of them - I've had it get stuck on my laptop cord, and then again, you have to go manually untangle the cord and move the roomba to get back on track.Regardless, the Roomba purchase was well worth the money for me - I hate vacuuming, and this has saved me the trouble of adding it to my to-do list. The noise is slightly quieter than that of a manual vacuum, too, so that's an added plus. Maybe one of the best features is the app compatibility. The push notifications on the phone alert you if the Roomba is stuck on something, or if the battery is running low, and you can choose to send it home if needed.All around, I'd recommend this purchase to a friend. It might be a little more expensive than a manual vacuum, but to me, the convenience pays for itself.

And it's that last that has me quite annoyed, as it seems to be a really bad error in its programming.When the vacuum gets stuck, I can at least open the app and hear it (usually) complain. When its battery dies, though, it won't respond to the app at all, and I have to hunt all over the house to find it. Surely it could be programmed to give up finding its way back while it still has battery left? The chances that trying just a few minutes longer will result in success seem kind of low if it hasn't actually detected the charger, so it might just as well give up and save its battery.And speaking of which... there should really be a 'find' button on the app so that I don't need to quit it and start over again to get it to make noise.A few years ago, this was probably state-of-the-art. X1: I bought the Roomba 675 because I saw it worked well with pet hair and I own 3 dogs and 2 cats (plus my roommates 2 cats at the time of this writing). I really should have done more research before I purchased this and I've had this Rooma since March 22, 2020...Pros: works great on LIGHT colored carpet, easy to maintain (I use a dog grooming brush to clean the bristles of the copious amounts of animal fur), it's easy to locate with the location chime, and the app is pretty straightforward with reminders to clean the brushes and change out the filter.Cons: if you have ANY dark marks on the carpet, the stupid things sensors will get stuck because it detects a "cliff" which will then require you to move it to a new location before it can resume operations; it doesn't have very good mapping technology. It goes around the same way and has completely missed rooms and obvious spots of my 1200 sq ft house (half of which I don't even have it clean!) even after I set it up over the uncleaned spots; the battery doesn't last very long (1-1.5 hours of run time before it dies) so if you have a large house you will need more than 1 to clean all of your floors. The battery has died just doing my bedroom, which is only 120 sq ft.Overall, just having it do my bedroom is mostly awesome but the rest of my house is never clean unless I manually vacuum or sweep it. Either the battery dies before it finishes, it gets stuck on the dark patterns on my large living room rug and I refuse to get it since it happens CONSTANTLY (at least 5-6 times in the same spots each time it runs; hence why I say the mapping technology is rubbish), or it just doesn't go into the other rooms.I wish I had gotten a different Roomba...

X1: I thought there was good chance that our new friend "Norbert" would spread cat litter around the house (more than it already gets spread).  However, Norbert does a surprisingly good job.  He has not fallen down the stairs either which is a huge plus.We have found that if we lock Norbert in a room by himself that he does a better job than if you give him full run of the house.  His mind has a tendency to wander a little in that regard so constraining his territory makes it more likely that he'll find all of the cat hair "tumbleweeds", litter, dirt from outside and other stuff that happens to hit the floor.Norbert, despite his relatively low IQ and seemingly random movements, apparently recognizes both of our cats and apparently has an appetite for cat tails.  Our furry friends have decided that avoiding Norbert's brushes and wheels is best and make for high ground when they hear him start his cleaning routine.Overall, Norbert joining our house has made our lives easier by giving us time to no longer do the vacuuming ourselves and instead spend time watching him creep across the floor, under chairs and into some of the areas of our house that we realize that we should have vacuumed ourselves before he came into our lives.  Never has an animated object garnered such attention and entertainment in our house from all of use (cats and humans).  We cheer every time he finds a chunk of dirt and face-palm when he bumps into the same four legged chair for a few moments.  If the cats decide that they decide he is a mode of transportation for their lazy asses, I will update this review.  However, the manufacturer says that Norbert is not a cat transport device (contrary to ample evidence supplied by YouTube).

X1: I spent quite a bit of time researching robot vacuums and for what I wanted, I landed on this one. We have 2 medium - 55lb dogs. 1 with short hair and the other with long hair so that's truly my biggest focus. We also have carpet and hardwood floors so I wanted something that would move easily from one to the other. With that said, I'm impressed with how well it transitions. Even with rugs on the hardwood, no issues. I'm also happy with how easy set up was and how easy it is to get the robot going / scheduled. Literally tell it to clean (push the button, tell Alexa, push clean on the app, etc) and it takes off.  I read reviews that the 675 is better with dog hair compared to others in their 900's series so that was honestly a deal breaker for me. Cleaning / emptying it after it runs is also super easy. Personally, we didn't want to put tape on the ground so I liked that we didn't have to with this. It has gotten stuck on the bathroom rugs so before we run it, I just shut the bathroom doors - not a big deal. But the cons.. The biggest is it's so loud! We were hoping to schedule running it at night, but that's not an option as it will wake you up even if it's just on the other side of the house. The other con that I've honestly "gotten over" is the random lines it creates on the carpet. It jumps all around so afterwards, don't expect pretty straight lines like you'd create with a vacuum, it will look more like a maze is on the carpet - super random lines.

  <U+00A0>I will start off by saying that the iRobot Roomba has definitely helped my family with the day-to-day cleanup.My wife and I recently welcomed A firstborn son into the family. In the beginning, it was a struggle to keep up with the household chores while one of us went to work and the other stayed home.  The baby did not like the loud vacuum we had, and taking the vacuum in and out each day was a big hassle, not to mention took one of us away from the baby.I purchased this product so that it could do the cleanup after feedings, and pick up the items that we might have missed. Out of the box it worked fantastically! Yes it runs around the room a bit randomly, but it¡¯s still gets the job done hugging the walls, and doing the different rooms that we have. The vacuum is decently quiet for what it is able to do, and on multiple occasions has not woken up our son when he is sleeping in the evening and for daily naps.This model does not have room recognition, so it will clean any area that you leave open. If you really want that level A vacuum where you can ask her to clean specific rooms, go with a newer model.The only issue that I have right now with the Roomba, is that It will not go onto our very short shag carpet. I had a Hoover robot vacuum and the app to run it was terrible and after a year the whole thing stopped working completely BUT it would sense things and stop before running into it, and prior to first use, it ran a cycle and scanned your house for a map (we had to redo ours because it thought the dog was a piece of furniture and would never vacuum over that spot lol). X1: This is our second one of these and they just don¡¯t hold up.  It will last until just out of warranty and then things start to break.  The same stuff that was poorly designed on the older models is no better on the newer model.  The side rotator brush motor has plastic gears and they wear out quickly, which requires the entire module to be replaced ($40 or more).  The shaft of the side brush motor gets easily wrapped and filled with hair which is tough the clean out, contributing to the motor module breakage issue.  The shafts of the bottom brush and beater also get twisted up with hair and are a pain to clean off.  The thing gets hung up quite easily by furniture, edges of area rugs, refrigerator, etc.  I feel like we are constantly rescuing it from situations.  You can use the invisible barriers, which do work, but you¡¯ll need a bunch of them in an average home.  Eventually, you¡¯ll have nothing but barriers and only half of your floors actually getting cleaned.  There¡¯s got to be something better out there for the price.  We are moving on to try out another brand.

  <U+00A0>I bought both the eufy and Roomba robot vacuums but I have to say I preferred the eufy brand. I did some research for many months on the type of robot vacuums to get and glad I went with eufy. Roomba is a very popular brand and there¡¯s a lot of rave about it but I honestly don¡¯t know why that is. It is super loud when cleaning and gets aggressive when it hits obstacles. It has a random motion like other robo vacs in the price range so I didn¡¯t see why it was much better than other robot vacuums. I also loved that my eufy came with a remote control which the Roomba doesn¡¯t and I find that handy if I want to quickly clean a particular spot. Here are the pros and cons to the Roomba but I¡¯ll go with eufy!PROS:-Since it¡¯s a popular brand, it¡¯s been known for its reliability.-Voice notifications from the robot-Easy to use app-I like the detailed cleaning notification on the app-Alexa enabled-You can click the home button from the robot itself. I didn¡¯t like that my eufy didn¡¯t have this function but luckily the newer model does.CONS:-Super loud!! Yes that is a huge turn off!-Bigger than eufy so makes it hard to go under furniture-Quite aggressive when cleaning..when it reaches obstacles it always wants to push through rather than go a different direction.In conclusion I prefer my eufy to Roomba.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2020

X1: Every negative review is some sort of person expecting this machine to be incredibly intelligent and the greatest clean they have ever gotten. That's not what it's for.I work 12 hours a day. I don't like to vacuum and I maybe would do it once a week or two, just because i'm not trying to lug out the vacuum and do this with my day off. I have a cat and i wear shoes in the house, so it needs it. My girlfriend wants to be barefoot in the house but it was always kinda gross to do so.Now I have this robot. I have it scheduled to go at 12 every day besides the days I'm off. I get a message at around 130 that he is done. I get home and the floor is vacuumed. I walk barefoot in my house and it feels clean and looks clean. My house went from being vacuumed 30 minutes biweekly to an hour and a half daily and I do nothing.This is not a search and destroy missile. It's not the deepest clean your house will ever get. It is essentially an RC car with a vacuum on it that won't fall down the stairs and do an 8/10 job 7 days a week while you do stuff you actually want to do with your life.

X1: We bought 2 Roombas about 6 months ago to clean 2 separate floors in our house, and it was a challenge from the start. It's gone downhill since. This review will describe the product in the first weeks and recent month.1. First weeks. They did a good job of picking up pet hair (2 large dogs) and child crumbs and filth. I liked how they can "dig" around chair feet to grab hair that was stuck to the chair feet. But they were LOUD. So loud that they could not be used unless we were out of the house or put on headphones. They weren't very "smart" in that they didn't seem to cover ground efficiently, but they "usually" got the job done. I say usually, because as often as not, they wouldn't find the base, or they would have trouble docking and couldn't charge. The base is so light that when the vacuum tries to dock, the base just spins around with it. It helps to put a rug underneath if you're on hardwood, but this is not foolproof. Sometimes, they would get lost and didn't make it back to base at all, so I often had to play "find the Roombas" with the kids. The Roombas missed charging often enough that I didn't even bother trying to set up the programed features, so I can make no comments about the programs. Still, my house was more clean, so I dealt with the noise and charging hassle without too much annoyance.2. Recent month or so. As I said, it's gone downhill. Neither Roomba charges at all without some intervention on my part. As you can see from the photos, one must have a very heavy stone weight placed at a certain location to the right in order to charge. The second one must have a lift from underneath. Even with these interventions, neither Roomba charges fully, ever. The one with the cardboard underneath only runs for about 20 minutes before dying in a random location. The one with the heavy weight runs about 40 minutes before death. Well short of the 90 minute run time they claim. In turn, my house isn't clean, and the fur piles are starting to accumulate.Based on the very short life span of these devices, a 1-star rating is in order. I am currently browsing for other robot vacuum options.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2020

X1: Replaced an Evovac robot with this one when it died after warranty had expired (of course).  Was disappointed that the Roomba was much louder and it rarely returns to its docking station.  It more often than not stops in the middle of the floor and you hear the message "please charge Roomba".  Have moved the docking station a couple of times trying to find a more centralized area but only marginally improved docking success.  Never once did my Evovac fail to dock.  The dirt collection bin also cannot be washed because the electronic wall sensor is in that bin and washing it would damage or destroy it so all you can do is wipe the inside with a damp cloth.  Poor design IMHO because there are nooks & crannies in the bin you just can't clean.  Today, the Roomba stopped in the middle of the floor and no message at all.  All the app said was it had lost connection to the cloud.  Put it on the charger and it wouldn't charge at all.  So here's the one really good thing.  I called tech support and they were able to walk me thru some troubleshooting.  Took it all apart,  cleaned it,  removed and replaced the battery and was finally able to get it to light up and start charging.  The agent was very competent, thorough,  and pleasant to deal with so 5 stars for customer support.  3 Stars for all else.

X1: OK. I am in an interesting position where I can compare 2 of these vacuums. I previously owned a Deebot N79. It ran for about 3 years with a battery change last year. It finally stopped charging even with a new battery. So I bought a Roomba... Ok, I have 2 small, husky type dogs that blow their coat every 6 months, a cat, and laminate floors with a couple of fluffy door mats. The house is open plan but has quite a bit of furniture to negotiate. So both vacuums had the same task. The Deebot was better.1. The Roomba only has a single front brush. So bits tend to get flipped across the floor. Also when it circles, it circles on the brush side, which seems counter-intuitive2. The Roomba is noisier, quite a bit loader.3. The Roomba moves faster, tends to overrun dirt rather than always picking it up4. The Roomba sits higher. Pros and cons for this. It doesn't get stuck so often under cabinet overhangs, especially the kitchen.5. Finally, the fuzzy logic/AI that creates the 'random' path that the machine tracks around the house means the Roomba doesn't cover the whole house. This was the most frustrating part. I would have to keep relocating it to a part of the house it hadn't covered because it would become 'obsessed' with a specific part of the house. When the machine had bashed your ankles for the 5th time in the kitchen yet hadn't even got into the front room, its just irritating.Both machines would run for about 2 hours on a full charge. Both would need regular emptying, especially in shedding season. But the Deebot did a better job of cleaning and covered more area. These are both older models so it interesting to see how a newer version would cope. Also, I never used the wifi connectivity, which was available on both. I was happy to press the button when needed. But I do appreciate having a robot vacuum, very useful.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2020

X1: I seriously love this little vacuum. I live in a 1000ish sqft apartment with mostly linoleum floors. I also have 2 cats and because of my allergies, I use silica cat litter. Anyone else who uses silica litter probably knows, stepping on a single piece isn't fun. Also, the amount of fur around my apartment was ludicrous. This vacuum helps so much. It doesn't have a huge capacity wastebin, but, for my apartment, it is plenty; provided I empty it after it runs. I have it linked with an iRobot account and my Alexa, and I love the expanded features, like being able to start it from anywhere in my apartment. I haven't tried to schedule it yet, I'm not sure how well that would work considering one of my cats likes to try and start it, and he knocks it slightly off the base. (As of yet, he hasn't figured out the button starts it, but I'm sure that is only a matter of time.) I check the robot every morning to make sure it is charging and run it in the mid-afternoon, when the cats are napping and unlikely to mess with it. I have to say, I run this every day, and I am constantly surprised at how much it actually picks up every single day. I didn't know how much dirt gets tracked into my apartment until I bought this vacuum.My one complaint, is that the front wheel gets a lot of fur stuck in it. While this doesn't affect the running of the vacuum, it is one of those little things that bugs me and is surprisingly hard to clean out.The one feature I would love to see tho, is a locator. Like a little beep you can activate if it gets stuck under the couch or bed, or something similar.

X1: This vacuum's a glitchy mess. It requires constant baby-sitting and doesn't save any time.Half the time, it can't dock by itself. It just runs until the battery runs out, and depending on your house/apartment, it might be hard to find and rescue. Manually docking it is really annoying: it needs to be positioned extremely precisely or it won't charge.When it does dock automatically, it usually doesn't charge. I have to wiggle it around for 1-2 minutes until it starts charging. The scheduling feature in the app is pretty useless since I have to do everything myself anyway.There are problems while it's vacuuming too: it often gets stuck, it often gets clogged, it bumps into things violently. Sometimes it gets stuck on nothing. It often yells ERROR 23452345 CHECK THE APP. But there's nothing in the app.There are even problems while it's docked and should be doing absolutely nothing. Sometimes it randomly starts vacuuming in the middle of the night. Sometimes it randomly yells ERROR.The app is poorly designed. You know how you can schedule repeating alarms on iPhones and Androids? And you can disable those schedules without deleting them completely? Seems like a no-brainer, but the Roomba app doesn't let you do that--you can only delete schedules.Definitely do not get this if you have pets. If a pet poops or vomits, the Roomba will smear it everywhere. The manufacturer's official solution is that you should inspect "floor conditions" every time you vacuum. So it's yet another task you need to perform yourself. Even if you can get past the "poopocalypse" problem, there are plenty more. If a pet slightly bumps into the Roomba, it just starts vacuuming.There are many other issues when the Roomba works "correctly." It's loud and it takes 1-2 hours to vacuum. No using the phone for 1-2 hours then. It requires frequent brush cleanings--much more than a regular upright vacuum. It will sometimes randomly ignore some rooms. Very unreliable.

X1: I bought this Roomba 675 when it was on sale on Amazon for $200 back in January. It¡¯s a ¡°manual¡± model (no fancy home-mapping feature), which was just right for finding out whether or not this concept would work for us. It didn¡¯t hurt that it was recommended by The Wirecutter.After running it on manual over the first weekend, I set up a Monday - Wednesday <U+2013> Friday schedule. By Wednesday of week one, I noticed that the dirt cup was completely full every time, so I expanded the schedule to every day of the week except Sunday.For the balance of week one through Monday of week two, the dirt cup continued to be full at the end of the run. On Tuesday and Wednesday of this week, the dirt cup was less than half full on both days, so I reverted back to the MWF schedule. The dirt cup was only about a third full after it ran on Friday.It looks like we¡¯re finally getting caught up with cleaning the floors downstairs after about a week and a half of running the Roomba almost every day. If the amount of dirt in the cup continues to go down next week, I may cut back to a twice a week schedule.So far, I¡¯m perfectly happy with this model, even if I do occasionally have to get it unstuck or help it find its way back to its charging station before it runs out of battery power. Our downstairs floor is cleaner than it¡¯s been since right after we moved in over two years ago. I don¡¯t think that we need either the whole-house mapping or self-emptying features of the more-expensive models.I have no illusions about never having to use our upright vacuum cleaner again, as the carpets and rugs will need periodic deep cleaning, and there will always be places that the Roomba won¡¯t be able to get to. Manually emptying the dirt cup after each run gives me useful feedback on the efficacy of the current schedule, as well as giving me the opportunity to vacuum off the dirt filter each time (to extend the useful life past he recommended 1 month).Note that I work from home, so I¡¯m here to keep an ear on the Roomba while it¡¯s moving around the house. As it gets stuck about once every time it runs, I¡¯d definitely say that YMMV if you¡¯re planning on running it when you¡¯re not at home (and depending on how many ¡°robot traps¡± you have).I have noticed that how long it can work depends on where its random path algorithm takes it. The more time it spends on carpeted areas, the shorter the run time<U+2014>about 70 minutes if it¡¯s staying on carpet, compared to about 80+ minutes on tile or wood flooring.Installing the iRobot Home phone app was a big help, both for the initial setup and for controlling the Roomba. It also generates push notifications if the Roomba gets stuck or confused and needs assistance to resume cleaning.

X1:
Your browser does not support HTML5 video.

  <U+00A0>I own three tabby cats and one husky dog, all of whom shed an insane amount of fur. I'm also highly allergic to all of them in addition to suffering from seasonal and dust allergies. (Benefits of pet ownership > my sinuses, apparently.)My house is also quite large. I mainly use it on the main floor, which has a very large and open family room, dining room, kitchen, front entryway, bathroom, and back door area. I also move the Roomba to my upstairs floor to clean the bedrooms. All rooms have hardwood floors with a few area or entry rugs. Prior to owning the Roomba, if I wanted fur-free floors I had to vacuum at least twice a week while wearing a filter mask to avoid sinus infections. I was so exhausted of the upkeep.I was worried that the Roomba wouldn't be able to keep up with the amount of fur in my house and/or would struggle with the transition between rugs and hardwood, but I decided to risk the expense. I'm so glad I did and wish I had bought one years ago!!!!The Roomba is an excellent option for keeping up with daily pet fur and small messes on hardwood floors and carpet. I set it to clean once a day on my main floor, and two or three times a week I carry it upstairs to clean. Every evening I use my large, upright vacuum to vacuum out the Roomba's canister and filter, which takes about a minute's worth of time. Check out my photo to see how much it picks up on my main floor every day! At least once a week I inspect the bottom of the Roomba to check the brushes. Sometimes I remove the brushes and pull or cut out out any stuck threads or fur.It takes about an hour and a half each day to complete its job on my main floor and usually returns to the home base to charge again without issue. If the house is particularly messy I let it charge and run it a second time, but I don't usually need to do this. Sometimes it misses small sections of floor, but since I run it every day it usually hits everywhere at least every other day.One small complaint I have is that when the Roomba moves off a carpeted area or rug and onto the hardwood floor, sometimes it leaves small chunks of fur that must have been caught underneath it. (See my second photo and video.) Considering how amazing a job it does on a daily basis on keeping the hardwood floors fur-free and what my upkeep used to be I'm not going to complain too much about this inconvenience, but I hope that the engineers at Roomba find a way to improve their product over time. Maybe the suction power needs to be increased?The Roomba has greatly reduced my need to do frequent vacuuming and now I can get away with a deep clean vacuum job once every other week. It has been a mental health and sinus saver and I'm so glad I bought it!
X2: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2020

X1: If your room is anything more than a 10ft square with little to no furniture don't bother with this vacuum. The damn thing can get itself stuck just fine, but can't seem to figure out how the eff to get out from it's newfound prison.Two stars because the build quality is fine, I'm feeling generous.Just burn your money and you'll have less pain than owning this thing. If you want a decent robovac go for one of the LiDAR bots with a mapping and virtual wall feature. I've had one for a little while now and have booted my Roomba up to the attic. Fun fact, it still gets stuck even though it's a basically square room.UPDATE (July 20, 2020): My Roomba now cannot detect when it is hurtling itself off of a ledge and after 2 minutes of "cleaning" the attic it will try and hurl itself down the stairs. Within 10 minutes of starting a clean it quits, having YET AGAIN thrown one wheel off of the staircase.DO NOT BUY THIS. IT IS A WASTE OF MONEY.

X1: I dreamed of owning a Roomba since I first saw one. Finally, I decided I would trade the suction and cleaning power of a real vacuum for the convenience of the Roomba. Unfortunately, it's the most useless piece of garbage on Earth. It cannot even finish a cleaning cycle.Oh, don't get me wrong. It often thinks it does. Because it's useless. Right now it thinks it has finished the job, because it's done most of my bedroom. The rest of the apartment is up to me, I suppose.This may be because of how difficult it is for the Roomba to actually do any cleaning. Originally, the plan was that I could take the dog for walks while Roomba cleans. But that's not possible because about every 90 seconds I need to move it. Roomba thinks it's near a cliff. It's not. Usually it's just sitting on hardwood floor. One time there was a small, half centimeter bump in the rug. That was Kilimanjaro to this useless robot.Now, you may be thinking "I'm sure his cleaning needs are much more than mine." Oh, but they're probably not. I have a 700 square foot apartment with no steps, and only a small carpet and one rug. Roomba still can't clean my place.Reluctantly, I gave my dream purchase one star. I gave it a second star because if the geniuses behind iRobot are any indication, we will never have to worry about robots taking over the world.UPDATE: I've included photos of things that are too difficult for Roomba to handle. Both of these Roomba could not handle as it was "near a cliff" requiring me to manual move it. The former you can clearly see the MASSIVE drop off from the rug to the floor. The second, it's difficult to tell because, yes, it looks perfectly flat, but that's deceiving. There's a slight bump in the rug!! Honestly I don't understand how I don't trip over it constantly. No vacuum, particularly not one that I paid a not insignificant sum for, could possibly handle a slight bump in a rug. I've limited the photos to two of the - no exaggeration - THIRTEEN times Roomba encountered an error on this one area rug and I have to pick it up, move it, and restart. What a great purchase! Thanks, iRobot!

X1: BOTTOM LINE: My floors have never been cleaner. As a busy young professional I simply cannot compete with something that will vacuum for 90 minutes per day, every single day.  For that reason I will likely be a lifelong customer of robot vacuums, most likely this brand.That being said, this device is not without issues.  The primary thing that I run into is that it gets stuck 90% of the time.  That's fine with me, and this point I just expect it, and then move it when I get home.  It will get stuck behind a couch, it will get stuck on staircases, it will get stuck if it runs over a shirt.  The other major problem is that it won't necessarily clean the entire house it'll just clean a certain area and think it's done.  If it goes into a room and then manages the shut the door of that room, then it will vacuum that area and then stop.  There's no map in this version so it just mindlessly roams and sometimes that's just in a smaller space.The last thing that I wish was different, was the loud "ROOMBA STUCK" announcement at 3am, if you forgot to re-dock the vacuum. Or, if the Roomba decides it's not placed optimally on the charging station, the vacuum will turn on and then move around a bit until its in a better spot (again in the middle of the night).All of that being said, this just feels like we are in the beginning stages of an excellent technology. My house is clean, and thats why I bought this.

X1: It's a good product and does what it claims to do.Pros:- Controlled on the app or on device- One can put it on an schedule- It does well knowing where stairs are and won't go off the edgeCons:- If you have any black or darker colored area rugs THIS IS NOT THE PRODUCT FOR YOU, unless you want to pick them up before each vacuuming. The sensor that makes this product "smart" at detecting extra dirty areas is also the sensor that makes it automatically shut off if it encounters a ledge. And because my area rug is black, it thinks it's about to fall into a black hole and shuts off.- Compared to a cheaper competitor's product, the Roomba costs about $100 more and does the same quality job. There's no "better" that comes with the extra $100 that you would expect.- This Roomba is a BRUTE. It's very "heavy handed" and hits things quite hard before it changes course. The cheaper product I owned by one of the iRobot competitors was much more gentle with walls/barriers.- All robot vacuums are loud but this Roomba is a little louder than others. Maybe it's because of power of the engine that smashes it into things so hard?OVERALL: Good quality product that is made well and works well. But for the price you can get a competitor's product for significantly less and it'll perform as well as this Roomba model. I'm sure there are higher end Roomba models so my review is SPECIFICALLY based on the Roomba 675.

X1: It was on sale and our anniversary so I went ahead and purchased it. After doing some research I landed on Roomba for couple different reasons.  First, it's the original robot vacuum company. Out of the box it cleans sporadically but I think it's starting to get better. I only purchased it to clean the wood floors/area rugs on our middle level. This area has the highest traffic between us, our 2 kids and our 2 cats.We were sweeping every other day and constantly had little pieces of dirt on our feet, so I thought let's give it a shot. This vacuum is not perfect but the floors have never been cleaner. It's not very loud and has a very decent battery life. We schedule it to clean in the middle of the night while everyone is asleep. It only got stuck 1 time because a robe belt got tangled in the brushes. We are very happy with our Roomba and look forward to it cleaning for us every day! The only reason I knocked 1 star off is because the 3 prong sweeper was torn after 3 cleaning cycles. I know these parts are changeable but hopefully this was just a fluke. I wonder what the v9 series is like considering how awesome the 675 is!

X1: The product does a decent enough job as far as vacuuming is concerned.  The app worked well and paired with the robot easily.  It's mapping doesn't seem very efficient, missing the same spots time after time.  I noticed that it would run over it's own home base during every clean cycle and the unit would simply stop in the middle of whatever it was doing after about an hour and a half.  When asked to dock, the unit either wouldn't, or it would roll over to the home base, run it over, then take off in a random direction.I talked to iRobot support, which was incredibly helpful.  They responded by email quickly and walked me through as many steps as possible to resolve the issue.  They then requested a phone call, which was quick and very helpful.  They used a neat streaming feature to watch what the unit would do when asked to dock.  Without much hassle, they sent me a new base unit very quickly (1 or 2 days later).  Unfortunately, the problem continued unchanged, even after performing a factory reset.Given that my concern seems pretty common, and issues like the inefficient mapping (if it was mapping the room at all, given that it would run over it's own base), I decided to return the unit to purchase a different one from another reputable company.I've used iRobot Roombas before, but they were all older units.  When I'm in the market for a higher end model, I would definitely consider another iRobot, but I can't recommend this one.  +1 star for excellent customer support.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2020

X1: I ordered this completely understanding that I would not get the robot equivalent of me sweeping and vacuuming every other day. I'm obnoxiously dedicated to a tidy, dirt free home. That being said, I am VERY impressed! It is quieter than a normal vacuum but not so quiet that I would run it in the middle of the night. I have two skittish cats who seem mostly unbothered by it which is surprising since they are usually scared of everything.Pros:It cleans up daily dirt and debris from normal foot traffic and my careless teenager.It sucks up the stray litter that normally gets tracked all over the houseIt fits under most tables and furniture vacuuming areas I rarely have time to get to - including under my bed!It handles the marble lip of my bathroom doorway like a champ and can handle 1" lifts and drops without much fussThe spin brush pulls dirt away from corners and baseboards into the vacuum. Much more efficient and clean than I expected.The app and sounds make management a breeze. I set roomba to run every day at 2pm and roomba texts me if anything goes wrong or when it needs help.Cons:It does not like my dark grey rug. It will do the edges but not much more and the narrow area between the carpet and wall confuses the sensor and roomba will shout out that it's stuck even though it isn't.It can be a bit too thorough at times. I have roughly 900 sq ft of space that we have roomba set to vacuumn and it spends 2+ hours vacuuming over and over until the battery is almost dead. Not complaining! But if you are trying to do a larger space it may die before it gets the job done.Which leads me to my next point - roomba has a hard time getting back on its docking station. I don't know if I need to move it or if there is a way to secure the station to the floor but almost daily when the roomba returns to dock it bumps the docking station and can't connect so it will then go back out and roam around for 20 more minutes trying to find the docking station again. It makes no sense. The battery occasionally dies because of this and I have to pick it up wherever it dies and bring it back. Again, for the time saved it's not a big deal but definitely a design flaw that could easily be remedied.Overall I love the product. Even with the cons, I can live with only having to vacuum our rugs occasionally and something else doing all the rest. This is the first time in years I've been able to walk barefoot in my house without dirt getting all over the bottom of my feet. I used to spend 3-5 hours every weekend caring for the floors and cleaning up our home. After roomba I spent less than 20 minutes on the floors and had time to tackle projects I never have time for! Totally recommend! Already told my husband I want the roomba with mop abilities in a few years.

X1: We have a blind dog and so far, from two cleanings, I am pretty sure if we attached a vaccuum to him and let him wander around the house, it would probably be a lot like watching the roomba work.  Lots of seeming aimlessness and bumping into things.  The roomba is also kind of loud.  Not unpleasantly so but is louder than I imagined.  And so far, during both cleanings the roomba has gotten caught up on the legs of our recliner which is apparently what it imagines hanging off a cliff to be like because that is the error message I get.  Now.  Let me tell you why you should ignore all that and buy this anyway.Now, I don't want to overstate this but basically, 'The Tiger King' on Netflix changed our life.  Our 13 year old daughter just randomly now blames EVERYTHING on Carole Baskin.  So, when we got the Roomba, she was DELIGHTED to know we could name it.  Guess what she named it? Yep.  Now, "...that b*tch, Carole Baskin" doesn't fit in the spaces allowed so we did have to settle for "Carole Baskin".  This name was chosen because we have four cats and "Carole"  just goes around cleaning up cat hair.This is important because when you setup your Roomba, you need to download an app so you can schedule, name and manage your Roomba.  When your Roomba gets "caught up on a cliff" like recliner legs in our case, your app will alert you that your Roomba requires assistance.  For example, my alerts look something like, "Carole Baskin is caught on a cliff.  Please relocate Carole Baskin..."My daughter HOWLS over this.At this point, being in quarantine and in a home that takes that VERY seriously, if this thing did not work for crap, I would still give it a 5 star rating. The hilarity and entertainment is just worth the money at this point, honestly.However, that being said, "Carole" works AMAZINGLY well.  As I said, four cats across approximately 1,500 sq. ft. of our first floor (of a 2 story home) 24-7 is a lot to keep up with and I routinely feel overwhelmed by the upkeep.  Our floors are SO clean!  I could not be more impressed at this point.Corners, edges, all of it... it's the best money I have spent in a long time which is saying something.  Being in quarantine, I have made some interesting purchases so far including a woodburning kit. I don't have wood, guys.

X1: Of the cheap robot vacuums I've owned this is the worst one. It is actually starting to fill me with anger whenever I have to deal with it, which is constant.I had an early Neato vacuum years and years ago, pet editon since I have two cats. It did its job, it was super simple, it couldn't go under my kitchen rolly-counter but it could get over the lip into my bathroom, it almost always made it back to its base unless it found a forgotten sock or loose wire. It had a mildly annoying beep if it was stuck but not incessent. It had shitty battery life though and eventually it died altogether.Then I bought one put out briefly by Anker, of course it had great battery, that was never a problem. It could fit under my kitchen cart, it ocassionally got stuck trying to get into my bathroom but usually it worked its way out of problems, it may have beeped once or twice when it first got into trouble but then would stay quiet. It usually made its way back to the base, but if not it had such great battery life that it didn't actually need the base for a couple days. Anker stopped selling them though and while I think they're probably the same as the eufy ones? but I wasn't surewhen I broke my Anker while cleaning it (completely my fault) I thought I would try Roomba. I mean, roomba is the big brand and should be better. While this is a cheaper roomba it is more expensive than my earlier robot vacuums.Why I hate it- It is loud as hell, but doesn't do any better job- it gets stuck on the lip into my bathroom every time where the others were able to go in and clean that room- it can't get under the kitchen cart, it also gets stuck on my desk and another thing in my office because of that wierd little outcropping it has on top- when it gets stuck somewhere, or can't find the base, or is low on battery, or is sitting on its base but not charging it both tells me via text message and LOUD voice message - the voice message repeats LOUDLY every now and again, like in the middle of the night.- It finds the dock every 3rd or 4th time it runs. I live in NY, my apartment is not big. The dock is in a very central place, the other vacuums had no problems with their docks in that spot.- On the rare occasion that it can find its dock It often fails to charge because it can't get its finicky self onto the charger correctly, my other vacuums just backed up and re-docked. I think I might be able to fix this by taping the dock to the floor, but that wasn't necessary with the other vacuums- it has shit for battery life. Yesterday it started up on schedule but I turned it off because I was in the middle of something, but it didn't redock ... it wasn't doing anything, there was nothing that should have drained its batteries, but today it is dead.- The neato used a pattern to clean, the Anker bumbled around at random, both always managed to hit my whole apartment. The roomba I have to keep carrying into my living room, from which it constantly returns back into my hall without cleaning the living room. I have to barricade the sucker into the living room to get it to clear the largest room I have. The other robots had no issues whatsoever with this, I don't even understand how it is an issue.The good?The app works really well with it, impressively so. I did have trouble initially connecting to the Amazon Echo, there was some sort of server error, but whatever the issue was they'd fixed it when I tried again a few weeks later.

X1: ETA 10/9/2020:  This unit does great on hard surfaces like the front hall and the kitchen.  It does great around the perimeter of the room and under furniture.  It goes over those areas about a billion times.  It's actually under the dining room table for the fifth time this morning right now.  We don't eat at the table, so there's only hair/dust for it to vacuum.  I'm sure it got all of that the first or second pass,What it doesn't do a good job of is the center of the room (i.e. the high-traffic areas).  Seriously, I think I could do better with dustbuster!  I think it would do much better if it went back and forth in a logical pattern instead of rambling around aimlessly.ETA:  I'm annoyed that when I use the app or the button on top of the robot to tell it to go back to its dock, it keeps on cleaning and cleaning and cleaning.  This morning, my cats activated it around 6am, and I heard it running when my alarm went off at 6:30.  I used the app to tell it to go back to the dock.  When I came downstairs a little before 7, it was still running.  I pushed the dock button on top of the robot, and it kept cleaning till the battery ran out, at which time I had to move the sofa to get to it so I could carry it back to the dock.The Roomba has run 5 times so far.  I ran it twice the first day since it spent most of its time on the perimeters of the rooms and not enough time in the center where the hair shedding feline monster spends most of his time.  I wasn't terribly impressed the first day.  I did learn how to get it to concentrate on a specific area, though.The second day was better.  It was able to figure out how to get into the front hall and the kitchen and did a decent job overall.  The cats managed to turn it on at 10 o'clock last night, but when they came charging upstairs I heard the whirring and used the app to send it back to the dock.  It's now running for the 5th time.I empty the bin after each run, and it's been full each time.  I'm absolutely amazed by how much dust, human hair, and cat hair it has picked up, and a little embarrassed that I didn't realize the carpet was so dirty!  Roomba even sucked up two catnip toys that it found hidden under the sofa the first day, but I was able to retrieve them.If it keeps cleaning this well, I'll be happy with the money I spent.

X1: I am a single, working mom (also in grad school) who has no time to keep up with all the cleaning a house requires, but not enough disposable income to afford a regular maid service.  Even with a hypo-allergenic dog and only one child, my floors get dirty daily; the dog's fur is velcro for leaves and pollen-y tassels that fall from trees, the child's shoes somehow end up on every surface imaginable, and crumbs are just a fact of life.  I'd recruit the kid's help but she's not yet big enough to do the job well.A couple years ago I tried to get a cheaper robot vacuum instead of spending the extra $ on a roomba, but ended up disappointed and frustrated with how much I had to "rescue" the vacuum.  It didn't perform any better than I did, so I eventually threw it away.Enter corona quarantine:  we are in our house 24/7 whereas before we were here to sleep and maybe 4-5 waking hours. Those extra waking hours walking across the floors magnified the problem: I realized I was spending at least 30 minutes per day trying to keep the floors clean, and not doing a great job as I have arthritis and bending is difficult.  I caved.  I need help, and decided to give robot vacuums another shot.  After extensive research and seeing the affordable price on Amazon, I ordered this Roomba and figured if it had performance issues like the last one I could just return it.It arrived and I could tell right away that the quality of the materials was superior to the previous vacuum - the wheels alone are like monster truck wheels compared to the previous one's toy-like wheels.  But did it REALLY perform any better?Yes. yes. yes. If I could marry this vacuum, I would. It cleaned my floors so well, I had to empty the canister twice on  the first run.  It has an app that lets you start it and send it home. I have been using it daily on both floors of my house, and it looks like they were just cleaned all of the time.  No more stepping on pollen tassels, wondering "is that a leaf or a bug over there?" or looking at tiny fluffy undercoat hairs that fly off my hypoallergenic dog.  This thing is a godsend. Total game changer. Do it.

  <U+00A0>We ordered the vacuum for our new house. We only use it for the open areas of the living room, dining room, kitchen, sun room and bar area. Finally, I decided to go ahead with the purchase after having assured myself that if I wasn¡¯t completely charmed, I¡¯d return it. I was both delighted and surprised to see this thing get to work. I have a household that needs LOTS of vacuuming: two cats, and three people with long, luscious locks. We run Major Tobo (as we have lovingly named our faithful assistant) once a day, and are consistently impressed with the amount of hair and dust that come up. Having the roomba has SIGNIFICANTLY decreased the number of times we need to pull out our Dyson. One half of our home is hardwood, and the other half is carpet- Major Tobo cleans both with ease. The dust bin is very easy to clean out, and we usually have to pull hair out from the bristles, but that¡¯s the case with any vacuum at our house. The roomba genuinely leaves our house looking clean- we can turn it on for a session before having company over and rely on it to have the place looking good when they get here. We¡¯ve had it for just about four months now and the only problem we¡¯ve run into has been it¡¯s habit of getting stuck on the fringe of our carpet, at which point I get a helpful alert to my iRobot app to inform me that Major Tobo is stuck and needs my help. Our cats (one of whom is an anxious boi) do not take rides on the roomba, but they remain unperturbed when Major Tobo is making it¡¯s rounds. Very happy with this purchase, I¡¯d recommended this product to anyone who has a busy schedule and likes to keep a tidy home.

X1: We have had our iRobot Roomba for a week and it's already made a huge difference in helping keep the house clean and picking up sand and dirt that comes in from our shoes.  I was really considering a more expensive version that had advanced mapping and other advanced features, but this one got so many great reviews I figured I'd give it a shot and am happy we did.I noticed a lot of reviewers name their robot, so my wife named ours HAL.  HAL is parked in the mudroom and has a 7am wakeup call everyday to clean our entire 1st floor.  Our 1st floor is open concept (kitchen, living room, dining room) and all hardwood or tile with a few area rugs.  It's about 1200 sq ft.  There's also a kitchen island HAL needs to negotiate and 2 separate rooms.  Sometimes HAL goes into those rooms and spends too much time there.  But for the majority of the time, HAL gets himself out of jams and manages to clean the entire 1st floor.I knew we would be emptying HAL's debris compartment, so I wont give a low score based on that, but I can definitely see the value in purchasing a more expensive robot that self-empties it's compartment.  The compartment doesn't hold a lot so we empty ours after every run.  But not having a more expensive one to compare to, I don't know how much better that really is.HAL tells you when he's stuck.  Today he got stuck under the couch by driving up and over a power strip.  I freed him and he went on to clean more stuff.  He's also never run out of battery, he always manages to find his way back to his charging station.I'd definitely recommend this product.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2020

X1: I purchased this on a flash deal for the roomba 675. I've been eyeballing robot vacuums for a while now, but couldn't justify the cost. I also have 4 cats and 1 dog and have been a bit paranoid about the horror stories I've read. Once it was delivered, I proceeded to unpackage it. Quick instructions on setting this up. I let it charge (which took less time than the instructions stated). Once it was charged, I set up the house with "barriers" in places I didn't want it to go. Shut the door to the mud room so it didn't go in there and then started it up.Off it went like a drunk uncle during Christmas dinner. It was banging into everything all over the place. I chalked it up to the learning phase. But boy, oh boy, did it remind of the drunk uncle stories. You know, that uncle that gets drunk during family gatherings, but everyone still loves. From this point on, I decided it needed a drunk uncle name. Mine is called uncle Otis.Uncle Otis went to town on my house. So much that I didn't think he was going to make it back before the battery ran out. On the app, I told it to go dock. Uncle Otis (like a typical drunk uncle) didn't really listen and just kept on cleaning. I think he finally staggered home, but barely. I really was not expecting uncle Otis to actually clean as well as my regular vacuum. I have an expensive Kirby vacuum and couldn't imagine this little guy could outdo it. I also had vacuumed previous to getting this just to give the poor guy a chance. To my surprise, the container was chalk FULL of animal hair and debris. I couldn't believe it, but uncle Otis was able to get a deeper clean than my expensive, fancy vacuum.Day two: I started uncle Otis up. Still banged into a bunch of things, but not as hard this time. I guess he finally started get some lay of the land. Poor guy was also going into nooks and crannies I couldn't reach with my regular vacuum. I think he became friends with a spider under my entertainment center. He came out fully decorated in spider silk... Only catch today was that he tried to get under the coffee table and got stuck. Had to free him and start him back up. Off he went again. After he was done cleaning, I emptied him. The container was 3/4 full of hair and debris. Man, uncle Otis is a beast!Day three: I gave uncle Otis the day off.Day four: I was working from home, so I started him up and went upstairs to work. I swear, about every 10 minutes, uncle Otis was stuck under the coffee table again. I finally let him have his way and raised the coffee table with some wood blocks. Uncle Otis was happy he could get under there. Still a decent amount of hair and debris after the run. I'm not sure, but I think uncle Otis is trying to mess with me. Either that, or my animals are filthy!Overall, I am extremely happy with this purchase. Uncle Otis does a great job vacuuming. He hasn't had any problem transitioning from carpet to hardwood floors to rugs. I even braved taking him upstairs to clean. I was a bit concerned about him stumbling down the stairs, but he was great at stopping before the great tumble. It is a bit scary, as he does head toward the edge at a pretty fast speed. But he never once tumbled.He still picks up a ton of hair and debris. This actually makes me happy as that is nasty that I could be breathing. And it's wonderful having a happy little robot that can vacuum while I do something else.Every once in a while, he has his "moments". The last time I ran him, he had somehow knocked the charging station into the middle of the hallway and placed himself where he should have docked... But sideways. Goofy ole uncle Otis.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2020

X1: The robot does a decent job of bouncing around the house cleaning, but it does not learn its environment or make a map so it doesn't vacuum efficiently and I am never sure what rooms got covered. The purpose of the wifi is pretty limited. I have mine connected to my Echo and I can say "Alexa tell roomba to clean" and it will start the robot. This is nice because the charging dock is under a cabinet where it camps nicely out of the way, but also where I couldn't easily push the clean button on top. The app only shows that a job is started or finished, how long it took and if the robot got stuck or ran out of battery. I can remember only one time that the robot left it's base, cleaned for an hour and then made it back to its base by itself to charge. It usually just runs out of battery after about 1.5 hours and I find it somewhere in the house. After vacuuming for an hour and a half, the bin is always full of dust and crumbs. I keep a clean house and have a cleaner come twice a month. If you don't have a robot vacuum, you are likely living in filth and just don't know it. There are some obstacles it doesn't handle well. It will get wedged under my futon if I don't put something in place to block it from going under. If there is a phone charging cable on the floor it will get tangled up in it. Sometimes it sees dark lines in the carpet and turns as if it is the edge of a cliff. Jarvis (what I named my roomba) is kind of a dick to my one year old son and I think the experience will put some deep seeded mistrust of robots in his psyche.

X1: I absolutely love <U+2764><U+FE0F> this thing!!! I got it from Amazon Warehouse for a lot cheaper then buying it new and it came in the original box <U+0001F4E6> with all the packing as if new. It looked like someone opened the box then closed it and returned it. It had all original parts and booklets and was still in the new wrapping. The booklet says to charge for 3 hours but I recommend charging longer before you use it for your first sweeping <U+0001F9F9> job. It was really easy to hook up to WiFi and the Roomba/iRobot app gave you step by step easy instructions that I believe anyone could follow and set up this lil guy. The app allows you to control the Roomba and start/stop jobs; return to the dock; and make it play sounds when you want to find it in your home.  It dose excellent in the space I have it set up for and cleans 3/4 rooms no problems. I honestly was shocked after emptying the dirt/dust bin on this and seeing how much was in it considering I gust swept <U+0001F9F9> my floors with my Shark and Dyson about 2 days prior to running the Roomba for the first time. It dose good on carpet but obviously it will not deep clean the carpet as a standard vacuum. It handle the thick rugs no problem and leaves the hardwood and linoleum/tile floors spotless! I run it every day and am truly amazed on how much it picks up! It would do great at picking up pet hair as well. I am very satisfied with my purchase and may be ordering a second one for the other portion of the house <U+0001F3E1>. This thing saves so much time it is incredibly! Instead of sweeping sweeping every day or every other day I can sweep once a week or every other week with my traditional vacuumed and my house is spotless. My floors have never been cleaner and I am not ashamed to say it¡¯s because of my Roomba!

X1: With most products, you can count on large numbers of reviews to make a good decision. This is an exception, because your experience with it could differ hugely depending on the conditions in your home.For us the Roomba is useless. We got it for the main floor of our house, which is all hardwood. For the small areas of the floor it is able to successfully navigate, it is capable of removing the daily dust and small debris. But I would say for us its success rate of actually completing a job is about 1 in 50. Seriously, that low. It just always gets stuck on something, and I wouldn't say we have an abnormally complex home. It doesn't do well with floor rugs, usually gets stuck. And it doesn't do well with our furniture. Any furniture that stands 3 to 4 inches off the floor, e.g. the edges of couches, chairs, coffee tables with a lower platform, is just right for it to wedge itself under and get stuck rather than bouncing off, and it usually eventually does. Or it will manage to work its way under the furniture, be unable to work its way out, and eventually die. The very few times it has managed to "successfully" complete a job, meaning it has gone for a certain amount of time and finds its way back to the charging base, it has been clear that large areas of the floor were left untouched.Like my headline says, it will be hit or miss with your home. For us, huge miss.

X1: We won this iRobot 675 in a raffle. We had been thinking of getting one for sometime but weren¡¯t sure how it¡¯d work for pet hair on carpet. All in all we are happy with it. It has some good things and some bad.The good. It cleans up pet hair on carpet very well. We run it daily for our living room and master bedroom. It does a great job cleaning those areas. It even gets under the bed!  Once a week we put it in the kitchen and let it do it¡¯s thing in there. Over all it¡¯s pretty quite. You can watch tv when it¡¯s running.The bad. It¡¯s a bit of high maintenance. The bin needs dumped manually daily. The rollers need to have the pet hair cut off then about every 2-3 days. It does not map out your home, like some more expensive ones do. In return it will sometimes vacuum the same spot/areas multiple times. The battery life is very short. It last about an hour. If it mapped the house out and had a memory it could probably get the house done everyday. But since it doesn¡¯t we found that it can get the living room and master room done in one cycle. So be block off the other rooms. It does have trouble going from the transition from tile to carpet. It will get stuck. That¡¯s why we have to do the kitchen separate. We ended up buying a couple lasers to keep it out of certain areas. It some times get stuck on behind things or corners. It¡¯ll just sit there and the battery will die until we get home and put it back on the charger.  We still have to use the big vacuum once a week. But boy what a difference this little girl makes for pet/dust allergies.So it works and does a good job. You have to play around with it and see where it can and can¡¯t go, so it doesn¡¯t get stuck. Buy the lasers!!  We like coming home to clean carpets everyday!!  It¡¯s not perfect and needs some quick daily attention. But it is one of the less expensive models out there.  I haven¡¯t been able to get the cat to ride it. But he has figured out how to trap it under the rocking chair.I¡¯d recommend this model if your looking for something that gets the job done and don¡¯t mind cleaning it out daily.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2020

X1: There are a lot of similar choices now that the patent expired, but after very careful consideration I chose a Roomba. Why? First, it was on sale for $199. But other than that, my  thinking is that other, newer manufacturers simply cannot beat the experience iRobot has amassed since they invented these things long ago. All the little bits and pieces of feedback they received over the years I believe has made the Roomba machine a solid choice. For example, I was reading reviews for another brand that made clear a common failure was the rubber seal around the filter kept breaking and people had to spend another $9 or so to buy a replacment part, which the manufacturer happily sold you. I believe iRobot fixed all the little fails over the years and the result is a more reliable product. I have owned 3 previous Roombas and I watched each model add little features that addressed preformance and reliability issues.  The fact this model looks only slightly changed from the last one I bought 9 years ago tells me they have perfected it. With other manufacturers, they are still in the learning process and you are the Guinea Pig. Also, I have always received good, if not excellent, customer service from iRobot, which may not be the case, according to customer reviews, with some of the newer manufactuers.  Obviously, the lower prices of newer brands is tempting, and you could say having to spend extra for replacement parts still costs less than a Roomba, and you don't mind the downtime, and the difficulties dealing with their customer service. But, I buy vacuum robots for the convenience and I place a value on reliability and customer service , so I chose to go with the brand I have always had a good experience with and it's worth it to me.
