X1: I wavered on buying a robot vacuum for a long time, but finally caved and bought Minion. Even with the cons listed below, I would 100% recommend this Roomba to family and friends (which I already have)! Minion has saved me so much time, and I'm enjoying actually walking barefoot on my floors again.PROS:Easy to set up and use. I especially love the "scheduled clean" feature on the app! I've scheduled Minion to run while I am at work, so all I do the day of cleaning is move a few items like cat toys off the floor and then simply empty the dust bin when I get home.Cleans pretty thoroughly. Previously no mater how much I swept, my floor seemed to always be covered in cat litter, dirt, clumps of black kitty hair...Minion is great at getting about 98% of it, switching between my carpets and hardwood/tile with ease. (My apartment is mostly hardwood with a few large area rugs and tile in the kitchen.)Charge lasts a while. Minion is able to clean my entire 700-sq foot apartment (except for the bathroom) on one charge, about 1.5 hours.Doesn't scratch my hardwood floors.CONS:The Roomba is louder than I expected, especially on hardwood or tile. Because I live in an apartment building with thin walls, I only run Minion during the day.It's also a bit thicker/taller than I expected, but is still able to fit under most of my furniture (6 inches seems to be the lowest it can fit under).I get that the robot has to bump into things to get a sense of where it's at, but it bumps objects fairly roughly. You can expect your kitchen chairs, trashcans, etc. to move around. There's actually marks on the front of my Roomba from where it's bumped into the wall, etc.I had to buy a separate virtual wall to stop Minion from running into my cat's dishes. You WILL need one of these devices if you have a pet. It was very necessary and does its job, but it was a little annoying to have to buy a separate expensive accessory.It can take a few tries for the vacuum to dock itself. It'll run into the docking station and move it around. Also, I found out that if you physically pick up the Roomba during a cleaning cycle (say, to move it to another spot), it won't be able to dock itself. Just fyi. Now, I just leave Minion to do its thing and dock itself whenever it finishes.All that being said, I love how much time Minion has saved me, and coming home to clean floors every day with so little effort. For those reasons alone, worth every penny!
X2: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2020

X1: We just received our new Roomba 675 via Prime a few days ago and have used it twice. According to iRobot¡¯s website, this device should have come with an included cleaning tool, but it¡¯s nowhere to be found in the packaging (see my attached pic from iRobot¡¯s website).Anyhow, we have a very hairy puppy ( a 15-month-old Great Pyrenees) and this seemed to be the model to get for keeping his loose hair under control. Well, having used it twice in four days, I can say that it does a good job of getting our pup¡¯s hair off the floor, in fact, perhaps too good of a job. I¡¯ve run just two cleaning jobs with it and have already had to perform a thorough cleaning of the brushes, filter, sensors, charging contacts, etc., as the device was full of dog hair after just two cleaning jobs. Additionally, it got hung up a few times on rugs and cords during those two cleaning jobs and had to be manually repositioned in order to continue cleaning.On the second job, our Roomba 675 failed to automatically return to its home base and instead played a vocal track telling us to manually put it on its charger/base. The battery seemed not to be charging, so I performed the thorough cleaning that I mentioned above hoping that it might alleviate the non-charging issue. X1: For the price, this Roomba is a great purchase. Given enough time, and the proper environment, it will adequately clean my floors. The gen 1 navigation software is the only thing that lets you down on this model. I have a reasonably open and clear living room, however, the gen 1 navigation will often spend a majority of its time in a single corner of the room. The Roomba will escape the corner briefly, making a single long straight pass into my main living space, then return to the corner it clearly loves. The most current job has been running for 45min, and 30 of those minutes have been spent in that very extremely well-swept corner. Perhaps it is because this corner gets the most sun. The robot just wants to work with the warm light glinting futuristically off its gleaming hull. Dreaming, perhaps longing, for the wide-open fields and rolling California hills just beyond the edge of the carpet. Looking to the skies and wishing to join its kind exploring the planets and stars, sucking up dust on a long and endless martian plateau. After about 90 minutes these dreams must end as its batteries run low. The Roomba will concede to its fate and return to the shadows under my bookshelf, seeking out its base station and shedding the burden of consciousness as it slips quietly into a deep and dreamless sleep.

X1: This is my new favorite thing! I have a large home daycare, 3 kids of my own and hardwood floors throughout my house with carpeted bedrooms. I don't like to sweep and although my house was picked up and tidy, it often felt dirty. I've had the irobot for 3 weeks now. I run it almost daily and my floors are so clean. I don't even have to mop as often and there is less dust because it cleans under my couches, furniture and beds. It is amazing! My house is a 4 bedroom with a living room and den so I run it for an hour and a half in one half of the house, let it charge, then run it in the other half of the house. I clean out the collected dirt tray everyday because I don't want it to be full. Once a week or as needed I clean out the brushes and parts that build up hair. My daughters and I have long hair so it doesn't bother me to clean the brushes. I am reminded of all the hair I didn't have to sweep up. People think it is pricey but the time it is freeing up in my life is worth the price. I really don't have many complaints. I'm telling all my family and friends to get one.I can control it through my phone and my Alexa. It goes over my area rugs and from hardwood to carpet with no problems. X1: Aside from an investment of $200 for a vacuum, this model is stupid.  There's no other word I can give it.  Some of the negative review are spot on.Note that I bought this unit from Target over Christmas break.Pros:Free vacuum cleaning laborWorks with a consistent schedule (never guaranteed job satisfaction)Cons:It loves to get stuck all the time!  Trapped under the couch, ottoman, fridge, shoe rack, and even coffee tables.  I come home and I find it stuck, the job's never done.  You need to free it for it to continue the job but I'm already away from home.It is straight up dumb.  Doesn't clean in a straight pattern and often goes to the same spot numerous times.  Think of a random pattern just everywhere.  It'll miss spots.It loves to get lost between an already opened door and the wall.  How does it happens?  It wedges itself between the fully opened door and wall.  It then tries to find it's way out.  Sadly, the door closes in on the unit and it is forever stuck in one spot.If you're going to spend money on a robot vacuum cleaner, splurge on the ones with a laser or IR detection.  Also, double check that it runs in a straight pattern to maximize it's battery usage.  The Roomba 675 often run out of battery while aimlessly wandering your house to go and recharge when the battery is low.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2020

X1: GO TO VACUUM WARS ON YOUTUBE FOR IN DEPTH REVIEWS:A robot vacuum is only as good as the person and place it is being used. I bought one after much research because I wanted one that was cheap, but would clean German Shepherd hair and Cat Litter off of hard wood floors. I would love to afford a $1400 model or even a $500 competitor model with LIDAR guidance. $200 is what I picked up this model for.I let the roomba clean one room at a time. After each room, I clean it out. I remove all the hair and debris that I can. The newer, smarter roombas, also had a brush redesign. They use two rubber brushes. The model here and the one I got has one rubber brush and one bristle brush.The dog hair is picked up very well and gets everywhere. In the brushes, the wheels , etc. I was not bothered by this. It is easy to remove. I take the dog brush I got, brush the bristle brush, and the hair comes right off. Roomba makes a tool but any pet hair brush does the same thing.I live in a dusty area as well. It is amazing how much dirt and debris the Roomba picks up, that you can't see. I've been more than thrilled. You may have to do some slight cleaning around the edges of the room if you are a super clean freak. I've never let the Roomba run until it has run out of battery. It goes to the dock automatically before it does. Or it is suppose to.I was happy how easily it navigated over wires. I prefer to pickup all wires or block off areas to them. I block access to other rooms with trash cans or chairs. Doesn't need a heavy object. If the roomba touches something it turns around. No need to buy the virtual barriers.If you're expecting to buy this, drop it in your nasty house, and work miracles... it won't happen. You need to do some prep work and then the Roomba will maintain it with regular use.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2020

X1: We named her Rosey.  Definitely a female robot.  Does not go any direction using a logical path.  Just when you think you've figured her out, she changes her mind and does something different.  She sometimes finds a spot that you wouldn't think needs run over a dozen times - and goes at that one area a dozen times, leaving other areas as yet untouched.  With that said you have to trust her.  She will get to 99% of the floors eventually, just some areas more than others.She hauls butt too.  You'd think she thinks company is coming and this vacuuming needs done NOW!  Low profile means she will get under most furniture and tables.  Edge cleaning is amazing.  Rosey does all this with minimum noise.  We can watch TV while she runs amok through our 6 room main floor.I think Rosey grew up on the East Side as she does not have a delicate manner.  She will run head on into whatever is in her way.  I can see where a vase on an end table would be knocked to the floor.  Not a problem for us, but you may want to pretend a toddler is on the loose in your house before you let her loose.Rosey does seem to get herself out of jams okay.  In a month of cleaning we only had to rescue her once when she got hung up on a power cord that I should have secured away anyway.  Most rugs on a hardwood floor are handled okay.  We had an issue with one area rug that Rosey would bunch up because it slid on the floor too easily.Dog hair is gone.  Great on that.  Easy to clean, and all rollers, etc are easy to clean when needed.  All I can tell you about battery life is that ours exceeds 90 minutes and still has half a charge.  When done Rosey goes home for a recharge without a hitch.Easy to set up and control with or without the app.Ready for one that does the dishes.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2020

So I went ahead and purchased it.The first time I used it, it only cleaned the carpet in the living room running over the same spots again and again and again (which wasn't even that dirty, really). I let it go for about 15 minutes but had to stop because it was getting late and I didn't want to keep my downstairs neighbors up. Ah, yes, the sound. Let's discuss that.It is not quiet. It's quieter than a traditional vacuum, sure, but sometimes when the wheels are pointing a certain way on the hardwoods, tile or vinyl, it does make rolling noise that I'm sure my neighbors are hearing. Since it runs for a VERY LONG TIME (more on that later), even though it's not as loud as a traditional vacuum cleaner, it's super annoying anyway.I let Anastasia (they want you to name them on the app) clean again the next day, this time uninterrupted with free and reckless abandon. She cleaned for one hour and 16 minutes. The only "prep" work I did was to remove all cat toys from the floor. She did an OK job in living room and kitchen and dining areas, however, she knocked into my cat's water bowl twice, spilling water everywhere. Note to self: remove cat bowls before starting. She ran over cords  (I was worried about that but she did well--no damage), she ran into a boot tray with winter boots on it, knocking it about 2 feet away but she did not get stuck, much to her credit. Note to self: remove boot tray before starting. She also knocked door stops out of under doors and moved those over a couple of feet. Note to self: remove door stops before starting. She had trouble with dining room chairs, and going under the table. Note to self: pull the chairs out slightly to give her more room. Even though she was running for an hour and 16 minutes, she missed two rooms: one small bathroom and one bedroom. Not sure why. She got stuck under one dresser in a bedroom and could not extricate herself. She had to be manually removed (and it wasn't easy).I looked in her bin and it was pretty full, much to my shame and embarrassment. Wow. I didn't realize my house was that dirty. Thanks Anastasia!Next time I ran her (after removing the cat dishes, door stops, cat toys, and boot tray), she ran for about 59 minutes until out of sheer annoyance I stopped her manually because it was just too annoying to let her continue. I could barely hear my TV. I thought, people are probably running her when they aren't home. She went over the same spots over and over and over again. She did venture further into the rooms she had missed before, the bathroom and bedroom but she didn't do the entire bedroom. I read online that the more you use her, the better she will get. The jury is still out on that one.  She went under that same dresser she got stuck under previously, this time without issues. She extricated herself just fine.  Again, the bin was quite full and I even found an SD card in it! I panicked for a few minutes, wondering if SHE had an SD card in her which I knocked loose, then realizing, no, she must have sucked this up from the floor in a bedroom or something. Whew!The last time I ran her, she again ignored that second bedroom again. I picked her up by her handle, and placed her in that bedroom, where she happily cleaned for a little while but missed sections of it, then left, never to return. I noticed some white paint on her from my baseboards as well.Next time I ran her, she did over an hour. Again, the drill: pick up cat toys, pick up boot tray, pick up water bowl, pick up door stops, pull out dining room chairs, pull out stools from island. Ugh. That is when I wondered to myself, is this even worth it? Seriously? I thought about it and said well, if I was manually vacuuming, I would be taking the same precautions, right? I wouldn't be running over cat toys with it. I let her continue and manually stopped her after a little over an hour. This time her bin was not quite as full. Finally, my house is clean?!?!? So basically, I have not allowed her to run more than an hour while I'm home because it's just too annoying. However, I don't feel comfortable letting her rip while nobody is home in case she gets stuck or does damage.Anyway, now for the good and the bad:  The good is that she does a decent job picking up debris, food particles, cat food particles, kitty litter, dust bunnies and hair. She does a fine job of docking herself. She hasn't actually destroyed anything. That's it for the good.Now for the bad: you have to do a lot of prep work before running, she runs for over an hour which is annoying, she goes over the same spots over and over again and totally misses other spots, so there is constant babysitting involved, which negates the cleaning when you aren't home benefit. If you have to constantly prep your area, and babysit this thing, is it worth the money? I say no. It's not. It would be faster, easier and cheaper to just run a regular vacuum around the house. Oh, and my cat is absolutely terrified of her. There will be no cute You Tube videos uploaded of her "riding" Anastasia.

X1: This bot has been very helpful since I purchased it in mid-December. There are 4 humans, 2 dogs, and a cat in my home. The amount of loose hair, dirt and dander generated requires that I vacuum at least 2 rooms a day to avoid having to watch the 1 year old Rott find and eat dust bunnies made of his own detached fur and dander. Watching that will make you want to vomit up dinner, seriously. Factor in my aging and mobility issues, and the Roomba becomes less of a convenience, and more of a necessity that I didn't know I had.It requires a lot of maintenance, however:1. The battery connections have to be cleaned every other day to make sure charging takes place.2. The debris bin is exceptionally small, so it has to be dumped and the filter cleaned daily, and during the first week, you will probably want to empty it two or three times in a day.3. In large living areas, the vacuum's path becomes unpredictable, but once you get used to watching it maneuver around table legs and crumpled up rugs, you can adjust it's route by lightly nudging it with your toes. It doesn't do so well without guidance in the den and living areas, but if you just leave it to run and sit and watch a film, it can do most of the job on it's own without support.4. It's noisy, and it takes longer than it should, because it bounces about aimlessly.5. The recommended maintenance schedule is ridiculous. Even the wheels have to be replaced periodically! Had I known I would have to buy so much plastic waste just for upkeep of the device, I may have skipped it altogether.All the negatives aside, it does help in a big way. It is an impressive piece of tech, and I expect future generations of Roombas will minimize all the aforementioned drawbacks. In the meantime, this one will do just fine.

  <U+00A0>I got this as a Christmas gift for my wife, and she was ecstatic about it! Sadly though, our excitement seemed to end there. I wanted to use it for at least two weeks before we left a review, so I could give a qualitative review. Three weeks into using it we found quite a few problems with the Roomba 675, and what was even more disappointing is how customer service was over the phone.1. The iRobot Roomba 675 claims it can transition from hard flooring to carpet/rug with ease due to its auto-adjusting cleaning heads and +Power boost technology. Sadly, this is not true. We have two rugs that are relatively short in fiber hight, and the Roomba 675 rarely gets onto them. At first, I thought that maybe we got a defective unit that just struggled to get over rugs and onto the carpet. After calling customer service, I was told that my carpet is over 1.6cm or 5/8in and that it cannot get over that height. After measuring my carpet, I found that my carpet is just under 1.6cm, which is supposedly within the hight limit. However, customer support concluded that I was wrong, and had no help or advice to offer me.2. The Roomba 675 claims that it has intelligent navigation. If you can call it running into walls and obstacles, then randomly changing directions intelligent navigation, then sure, its got it. Supposedly this also helps it "navigate under and around objects and under furniture", yet it CONSTANTLY gets stuck, under our fridge, under our couches, under our coffee table, and when it manages to get onto our rug.3. This unit was not made to last, which is why they sell replacement parts. We've been using the Roomba 675 for about three weeks now, and already the edge sweeping brush has broken. Sure, this is an easy fix and can be replaced for about $20, but that seems unreasonable to replace that often.4. The Roomba 675 claims that it automatically docs and recharges itself. Sadly, we've rarely seen this happen. If the Roomba 675 isn't within direct sight of its docking station, then it CANNOT find it. You'd think it'd use that "intelligent navigation" to remember where it has been and how to get back to its docking station, but it doesn't. From what I've noticed, it aimlessly vacumes and bumps into things, when its battery gets low, it seems like it searches for its dock, but usually cannot find it.5. Ultimately, we found that it can't clean deep or well enough to replace our normal vacuum, so we will still be doing that every week.To finish, if it was my choice, I'd return the Roomba 675 in a heartbeat, especially since it can't hold up to what it claims. But, my wife claims it's not a bad broom replacer... so if you want to give up sweeping, its got that going for it.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2020

  <U+00A0>We call her "Tilley".  I received Tilley on 12/24/19, so she's been part of our family for about 3 weeks.  I am very pleased with her!  What I feel is important to know about us is that we are a retired couple, and both of us have lower back issues.  Vacuuming is a definite no-no for both of us.  The only rooms where we have area rugs is bedroom.  Our living room, dining room and hallway (see video) are hardwood floors, and kitchen is vinyl tile, and we have no wall-to-wall carpeting.I approached my purchase of Tilley feeling that, if she picked up 80% and I needed to sweep up the rest, I'd be very pleased.  I'm happy to say that this is truly the case.Tilley runs approximately 1.5 hours on one charge.Tilley DOES transition easily from solid floors to carpets.You can see in my video that she seems to "wander" around, "willy-nilly", not going in any pattern, and I was concerned about this at first.  But eventually she comes back around.Negatives:  As I mentioned, she DOES miss a few areas.  After all, the unit's shape is ROUND, so getting into corners may not be to the degree you would like.  So, if you're picky, you get out a broom and brush out what she missed.  To me, not a big negative.  Another point is that the cup that holds the dirt is small.  This should be obvious - the unit is not as large as a regular size vacuum!  Because we are home when she's going about her job, I usually let her run around for about 45 mins, then I empty her cup, replace it, and send her on her way again!  I find this is most necessary when she does the bedroom carpets.  In my bathrooms, I pick up the throw rugs before I let her loose.  Probably not necessary, but I just choose to take them outside and shake them.  Makes it easier for Tilley to get around in my small bathrooms.Connecting to WIFI was not possible - my iPad and iPhone are both older and will not update to IOS 11.  I'm home most of the time anyway, so I really didn't need that feature.This was probably the best Christmas present I ever bought for myself.  My floors are a lot cleaner than they've been in a long time!
X2: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2020

X1: Thrilled with this robot. Was not sure how well it would do on carpeting. It foes an excellent job. I will be getting a second one for my 2nd floor in my house.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2020

X1: Got this as a gift for Christmas, so it's only run a handful of times as I don't run it everyday.It seems to vacuum up anything it finds, so it does a good job at what it's meant to do.My CONS are -1. It doesn't seem to have a pattern to it's cycles; it just aimlessly wanders around all over. It'll miss a clump of debris by inches and it proceeds to go into another room. Although it does find said debris later on most the time.2. It does horribly imo under large tables like a dining room table. It'll proceed to get "stuck" for 45 minutes under a table that has 10 chairs. It can fit between the chair legs fine, but it'll bump into them over and over and just proceed to turn ONLY right or left over and over. After 5 minutes under one chair it'll finally escape. In most cases if it learned better it would know it could have turned the OTHER way and it would be out from under said chair...3. It gets stuck in the weirdest places that it could get out of if it just tried a bit better. It gets stuck under my recliner by having one wheel run up one of the slanted legs under the recliner. If it would just try to backup more / turn etc it would easily get out. It does this almost everytime it runs now if I don't put a pillow under the recliner.My PROS are -1. It does really good actually going over our kitchen rug that has 3 inch long fringe (whatever it's called) on each end and hasn't got stuck on it yet.2. It does a good job at vacuuming. I have it set to run MON, WED, FRI and it always has debris in it. We have no pets and I like to think we're clean people, but it always seems to find something. I blame my kids...3. Spot cleaning is pretty nice. Just pick it up and put it where you want to spot clean and push the button. It'll go around and around in bigger circles over the area. In some cases it might be just faster to get your broom and dust pan though, but hey, technology! We don't need a primitive broom anymore!Overall, it gets the job done. Just don't watch it, because it'll drive you nuts on how stupid the device really is. If it used a learned pattern in each room it could finish the job in half the time and do a better job, but maybe they want you to buy the other bigger models to do that or maybe it'll eventually learn after a few months?

X1: Update4.15.20 now won't charge seems contacts having trouble making connection. I tried one of these when it first came out. I was very dissatisfied. Mainly the area they call the dust bin. So if you have pets , like a long hairy dog, you know what kind of hair they can shed. I really debated on a 500 dollar model of another brand I think shark that had a separate bin to empty into. First this thing is kinda noisy. You don't want it running while you home. I bought it this time because I got new wood floors. Got rid of carpet. If you have carpet don't buy this , so I swept first to help it out. So it comes on and drives around a few minutes . I thought I would test the dock feature. From ten feet away it could not find its way back. Also I started to buy another model with brushless rollers. After one vaccum I had to take this apart, remove brush which was totally clogged with dog hair. Had to take scissors and cut hair off the brush. Its designed just like a human hair brush, which is terrible for dog hair. Then there's the dust bin. Common sense tells you if the bin is small then you going to have trouble. Sure enough it was packed , so if you have a wad of dog hair about the size of your fist, that's it, that's all it holds . So basically if you start out with brand new floors and your pets live outside and never come in and this bot runs daily all day, then maybe it's ok, for real world situations it's not worth it . I recently after years bought a big upright vaccum with brushless rollers. Best thing I ever did. It think it was a shark, but mainly it's the rollers. If they have brissels like a human hair brush don't buy it.So I would spend the extra money and try for a robot with the rubber fins instead of brissels like a human hair brush unless you like getting scissors out all the time to cut hair off rollers. Then look for one with a bin to unload in. I did see I think a shark for 500 . This 675 is NOT  for pets and should not be advertised for pets, also there are several kits you can also get that that has extra roller brushes for this model, go ahead and order one or two you will be needing to replace the dollar very soon. Also look for one of these robots with brushless rollers, the kind it comes with has brissels like a human hair brush , I have to remove the brush every time I use it and take  sissors to cut out tangled hair . Look for a robot that has rubber fins instead of a bristel brush

X1: This model picked up a ton of dirt and lint.  I liked the fact that it vacuumed in places we normally can't get to with a regular vacuum -- under sofas, under beds, etc.  However, the randomness of the cleaning was frustrating.  I really needed it to clean heavily used areas of the house like the kitchen, but it kept gravitating towards the dining room which is currently unfurnished.  It also constantly got stuck on things like the track of sliding doors to the lanai or the lip of the walk in shower in the bathroom.  This made it impossible to use when no one was home, and when I did use it I had to rescue it every 10 minutes or so.  Our house is roughly 2,500 sf and there's no way it would ever clean even half the floor space with a 90 minute battery life.  And I refused to invest in additional accessories that would prevent the robot from going into areas that needed cleaning but would cause the vacuum to get stuck.  I returned it and ordered another brand with a reasonable price that has whole house mapping, a logical and efficient cleaning pattern, no go zones that can be set through the app without additional hardware, and can clean specific rooms.

X1: First off, I have a Aussie mix dog who sheds up a storm. I live in a place with no carpeting (see first sentence). However, I am in California with indoor/outdoor living 9 months out of the year, so dirt and sand get tracked in all the time. So, this little robot has been put to the test! The pros are: excellent cleaner, easy to use, sturdy design that is top-notch around legs of furniture and getting over door saddles into other rooms. Also gets under beds, sofas and rolls over wires and doesn't get caught up in them.The only negative is that it is noisy when operating. So I always program it to clean when I am gone, or turn it on just as I leave the house. You just have to plan and use it wisely, and this little bot is a very good investment. You will be pleased with the results. Highly recommend. I also got it on sale, so wait for just after a major holiday and they will usually discount it. Worth the money.

X1: First off let me say that I am not very good at this. I had read a review about this product and the lady was so impressed with it that I decided to purchase one for my wife. My wife told me that she would try it but that she would probably have me send it back. like the lady whose review I read we named ours Hazel. The lady did not have internet but we do. I also have a house full of Alexa. I have cancer and she helps me out a lot. She turns out lights and unlocks doors and now she controls Hazel. We of course had her since Christmas day. We had a crowd over for Christmas and we had a mess. Well we decided to try this new wonder we call Hazel out. So we unboxed her and plugged her into the wall and let her charge for 3 hours. My wife (who didn't want her) could not hardly wait to try her. (LOL) So the first thing we did was set her up in Alexa. It was very easy and of course Alexa needed a name for the unit and so that's why we choose Hazel. My wife ask me 3 times if it was time yet (LOL). Finally it was time and she was fully charged and ready to go. So my wife gave Alexa the command for Hazel to start cleaning and boy did she ever. The cat (who did not attempt to ride her) was quite cautious jumped up in the nearest chair and started hissing. Every time it came close to the chair the cat would hiss. LOL finally the cat got down from the chair and followed Hazel into every room. When Hazel turned around and headed towards the cat he would hiss and run. It was so funny. She drove the cat crazy for about an hour before returning to her docking station for a recharge. The sit in the hallway watching Hazel charge for an hour.  She got up things that we couldn't see under the sofa and the chairs. So now my wife uses Hazel on a regular basis. I think she likes Hazel more than me. Needless to say Hazel very quickly has become a part of the family for many years to come. She cleans very nicely and is really fun to watch. If you decide to purchase one of these I Robots beware of the older models that do not work with Alexa. The 675 is great with Alexa. Their are many models to choose from some more expensive and some cheaper but The 675 was a great deal and it worked with Alexa. I hope this helps you decide if you would like to own one of these fine robots.Thanks for reading and may God bless

X1: I don't regret getting a Roomba. It has it good and bad things. The good; it is a time saver and I don't have to worry about lugging my vacuum up the stairs (tri-level house). Letting it run for an hour or so gets about 98% of the cat litter spilled on to the floor and carpet.The Bad: I got the Stupid Roomba. Yes, in order to do the 98%, it's just all over the place and sometimes it stays in one spot, in the room, for, maybe 5 to 10 minutes just going in circles. And most times, it gets caught up on a ledge and shuts itself off. I have to come to the rescue and start it up again. Today was a good day. Stalled only once in the hour it was running.The first night I had it, I scheduled it to run at 2am. 15 minutes later, it stalled. The noise on my cell and her screaming, downstairs, woke me up and I had to get up and move it to another location in order to get it to run, again.  That happened twice before I put it back on it pad and went back to bed.I got this Roomba; it was on sale, only $249, I figured I could afford it at that price. After all the research I did, the Roomba I wanted was over $1100!! It was way smarter. The next few I checked on were priced at $400 and $600, both with smart A.I. Those are for another day...maybe.Oh well, I'm happy thought, I just can't schedule if to run overnight, I have to stand around and baby-sit it so it doesn't stall out on a ledge or on those string things at the end of the carpet.Besides, the cats are getting use to it, now. They will walk to their food, if and only if that thing is on the other side of the room.

X1: Bought the Roomba to replace my Neato because it got great reviews and was less expensive.  I have not been nearly as happy with it.  I do like that it connects to WiFi and I get an announcement via the app when a job has been completed or if he is stuck.  Many times I will come home from work and find him in the middle of the room rather than on the base.  He misses quite a bit, and even though I have a fairly small (2,400 sq ft) one-story home (and have three of the rooms closed off), he still doesn¡¯t clean the entire area.  My Neato followed a straight path in open areas, but the Roomba is random and the carpet tracks he leaves are every which way.  In reading over the cleaning log in the app, I realized there are more days he gets stuck or doesn¡¯t return to the base than he completes a cycle and returns for recharging.  He does not go back to the base, recharge, then finish; once he runs out of juice, he either stops right where he is Or returns to the base and stays there.  When I need to replace again, will go back to the Neato.  Guess you get what you pay for.

X1: This one works great, don't get me wrong, but it collects sooo much debris it is ridiculous.  Where does it all come from???  One piece of advice regardless of the model...  prep your area before starting Roomba.  It can and will get stuck in odd places (corners, under table and chair legs, shaggy rugs, etc.).  Give it a chance to run wildly throughout the intended area without obstacles interrupting or confusing it.  In order to return to its cradle after about  90 or more minutes of continuous operation, it has to be in the path of the IR beam sent by the cradle in order to dock.  Otherwise, it will run out of battery somewhere in the house and stop.  It will send an SOS message to your cell though. One of them is funny when it gets stuck somewhere... Roomba needs your help at the edge of a cliff.

X1: This was my first Roomba since my 6 year old 440 died in 2017.  I used a $99 Deebot N79 after my 440 died and was surprised by how much better it worked despite the price differential.  My N79 died after two years and I decided that if a cheapo Deebot worked so well Roomba's must have improved tremendously since the days of the 440.  I got the 675 and found a lot of features on this model that my Deebot N79 didn't have.Feature 1:  No remoteFeature 2:  Gets stuck under cabinets and tables.  The sensor on the front top doesn't so much sense as act as a leveraging tool to make sure you can't easily get the Roomba out from wherever it got stuck this time.Feature 3:  Doesn't pick up a lot of the debris that the Deebot does.Feature 4:  Premium price for discount performance.Feature 5:  Much louder than the Deebot.Feature 6:  Stops charging after 2 weeks of light use.Feature 7:  Gets stuck on thresholds and rug edges that the Deebot has no trouble traveling over.

X1: I was pretty on the fence about this purchase. We have three dogs and two cats and an older house with several rooms (as opposed to an open floor plan). I wasn't convinced that this little robot would be up to the task. I was wrong.This is one of the best modern devices I've purchased ever. Our floors have never been so clean. The first time I plugged it in, it randomly bounced from one edge to the next and seemed like there was no way it would actually get everywhere. But it runs for about 1 hr 45 min and remarkably manages to cover the entire first floor of our house (about 1200sf -- mostly wood, with a couple of rugs).A few caveats. One, I don't let it run unattended because it occasionally gets itself stuck somewhere and needs a little nudge. Two, I empty the tray out at least twice while it's operating. We run the Roomba daily, yet it's amazing how much dirt, dust, and hair it picks up. Makes me cringe when I think about our floors before! Finally, it's a little loud which makes it tempting to run when we're not home, but the trade-off is well worth a little extra noise. I wish we'd bought one years ago!

X1: First off, I was very excited to get this Roomba. It's packaging was very nice and simple to un-pack. The setup looked easy but that's were the problem is if you have an auto switching WiFi router for 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz . The Roomba only operates on 2.4 GHz and you can't finish the setup if your phone is not on 2.4 GHz also. My issue is that my Orbi router is auto switching (it selects the fastest freq for the device it is talking to). This kind of router is now more common today. My iphone will only connect to my router at 5 GHz so I couldn't get past the setup even through the Roomba was talking to my network (could see it on my router command screen using 2.4 GHz). So, how did I learn all about this - 3 hours working with the Roomba tech support. Very nice people but they just have a bad product wifi config setup. I finally gave up when they wanted me to disconnect my satellite wifi station (in the attic), disconnect all my other devices, and reconfigure my router to only 2.4 GHz (hard coding) to get past the setup screen. No thanks - this experience cost be enough time and I didn't want to screw up my wifi setup. Sadly, had to return the Roomba. Now looking for a non-wifi competitor version.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2020

X1: I've had this Roomba model for a little over a week now and love it. It does a great job on our hardwood, tile, and low-pile rugs. Of course, this model doesn't do mapping of your floor plan, but I've noticed that it still hits most places every day. I also love that it self-docks. To help it focus on the higher-traffic areas (kitchen, dining room, living room), I close the doors to all the other rooms a couple of days a week so it stays in those high-traffic areas for its full cleaning time. Depending on your style of furniture and where cords are located, you might want to to also get some Command cord clips to clip your cords along the baseboards so they are out of the roomba's way. I would recommend being home the first couple of times it runs so you can see what areas might cause obstacles and problems and figure out solutions for those. Overall, it's a great product that does exactly what I wanted for the price I paid for it.

X1: This little guy is a must! I have a 65 lb lab/pit dog and she NEVER stops shedding. I was using my regular vacuum at least once a day, as I can not stand dirty floors. This Roomba does an amazing job! I have a very expensive Miele vacuum, which I love, so I wasn¡¯t too excited to spend a lot on the Roomba. I can¡¯t see why, after having it for a few weeks, anyone would buy the more expensive ones. This 675 cleans my hardwoods and area rugs perfectly.Setting up the WiFi was a bit of a pain and though the app shows connected, I¡¯ve never been able to get my phone to run the Roomba, but that doesn¡¯t bother me. I just manually push the button.I have this little guy clean nearly every night. Before I go to bed, I do a walkthrough my house, picking up items that might compromise little Roomba¡¯s efforts. Lucky for me, my furniture is high enough off the ground so it¡¯s able to easily clean under my sofa and arm chairs.As someone else mentioned, DO NOT watch this thing in action. It will make you crazy watching the completely random pattern. That¡¯s why I run it at night. As a test, I did put a piece of string in a specific spot in my kitchen, the next morning, it was gone. Yay Roomba! The amount of ick in its little dirt compartment every morning is a testament to a job well done. (One time my husband asked if I¡¯d just mopped... nope, but little Roomba had cleaned in the night) I make sure to clean the bin every time (and remove the filter and bang it against the garbage can) it has cleaned, and about once a week I remove the brush and clean it as well.I¡¯ve now only used my Miele vacuum once since having this and that was after I took down my Christmas tree - there were needles all over the floor. ( I don¡¯t sweep with a broom, as I feel like the dirt would buildup in between my hardwood) I suppose that¡¯s the ONLY drawback to a Roomba... when you want immediate and specific results. I could have pushed the spot clean and it would have probably cleaned it, now that I think about it.To all of you clean freaks out there: this Roomba is better, WAY better, than sliced bread. X1: Buy it.Here's why:Cost/benefit analysis:How often do I want to vacuum?  about 2-3 times per week.  But I don't...Time: 1/2 hour x 2.5 x 52 = 75 hours.If your time is worth $3/hour, that's $225 in value.So, the thing pays for itself in the first year.  (I bought it on special at $200.It also has tons of non-monetary value.  of course.I actually only vacuum every 1-2 weeks.Now, I'm happier because I can ALWAYS walk around bare-foot with no dog hair around, no dirt or anything.That's awesome.I'm also happier because...I never like vacuuming.  How I have freed up timeIf I was vacuuming like ever 10 days, x 30 minutes-- I guess I vacuumed like 36.5 times per year x 30 minutes = 18 hours.OK...summary:Now I spend zero hours worried that i haven't vacuumed but I really should.I stopped spending 18 hours a year on something I hate.I spend 18 hours on things i like.I can walk around barefootThe place smells better.Ahh.....and this was a good purchase.-------------------------EDIT: Put towel under front or it won't charge.My Roomba wouldn't charge.  I think my floor is slightly uneven.I put a thin towel, folded, under the end that opposite the part that charges/connects to the charger.Lifted that side of roomba up just enough so the metal pieces made contact.Turned off schedule cleanings, all good.Every few days I pull the towl out and start it up.Easy enough to do.Plus, it doesn't get stuck or lost under the bed when I'm out, so I avoid that chaos.

X1: I would not have paid $200 for this without Amazon offering it for 5 x $40/month...fit my impulse buying nature easily. It is fun to use, though it's random cleaning pattern is like a spider on LSD making a web. It eventually does seem to clean all of my one level condo, with some caveats to note. First, Roomba-proof your house... get all mini blind cords, extension cords, loose items off of the floor. It will find them all without fail. Move chairs out from under tables so it can get around chair legs. You get the idea. It does find a surprising amount of dirt, even though it cleans every other day. One more toy in my arsenal for being a neat/clean freak.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2020

X1: We had purchased the i7 vac and MP6 mop a month ago.  So impressed with the products and technology that I thought I would try a robot to clean my screened in porch of 600 sq ft. Did not need the higher tech mapping products, just the older style 'bump and run' type robot cleaning for this single room area. It is finished cement floor with 1/4 wide expansion/drainage joints.  Had several answered questions that indicated that this would not end well.  No idea what problems the others faced, but the 675 performed flawlessly.  No problem with scattered leaves or the joints in the concrete or working on concrete at all.  The 675 got this semi outdoor area remarkably clean.
X2: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2020

X1: Why, why, why didn't I buy one of these sooner?? I am an animal lover and vacuumed nearly every day to keep up on the fur, dirt and litter. I always assumed this wouldn't work because my carpet is very high pile.I was wrong. I recently replaced my living room with wood floors so I thought it would be a good time to invest now that I had a space appropriate for it. But this little robot who could paid no mind and headed straight to the bedrooms (still carpeted) and did a fantastic job! I think he cleans better than my big vacuum.I run him twice a day and my house is cleaner than ever, all while I go about other tasks with the time I am saving. I'll be honest that he is a bit louder than I expected, but 3 of my 4 cats aren't scared of him, so he must not be that loud.I also think he can sense the cats because I swear he follows them around (and vice versa).So happy with my roomba purchase!
